What is this page?
This page lists the scientific contributions of an author, who either does not have a ResearchGate profile, or has not yet added these contributions to their profile.

It was automatically created by ResearchGate to create a record of this author's body of work. We create such pages to advance our goal of creating and maintaining the most comprehensive scientific repository possible. In doing so, we process publicly available (personal) data relating to the author as a member of the scientific community.

If you're a ResearchGate member, you can follow this page to keep up with this author's work.

If you are this author, and you don't want us to display this page anymore, please let us know.

Compared with Plonaphacarus aitu Liu & Zhang, 2015 and Plonaphacarus insolens Niedbała, 2000, all of them have short prodorsal and notogastral setae, but can be differed by: (1) sensilli long and setiform (versus short and fusiform in P. aitu and P. insolens); (2) all setae thicker (versus thinner in P. aitu and P. insolens); (3) posterior furrows of prodorsum present (versus absent in P. aitu and P. insolens); (4) robust median crista present on prodorsum (versus absent in P. insolens, weak in P. aitu); (5) lateral prodorsal carinae developed (versus absent in P. aitu, weakly developed in P. insolens); (6) 15 pairs of notogastral setae present (versus 16 pairs in P. insolens); (7) two pairs of notogastral lyrifissures present (versus four pairs in P. aitu, three pairs in P. insolens); (8) mentum h>h-h (versus h<h-h in P. aitu and P. insolens); (9) formula of genital setae 7(4+3): 2 (versus 6(4+2): 3 in P. aitu and P. insolens); (10) setae ad 1 and ad 2 long (versus short in P. aitu and P. insolens); (11) setae d on femora I not forked distally (versus forked in P. aitu). ...
